title: Inside crypto grants funding with Thrive CEO Daniel Jacobs

rawLines.text: call. Welcome to the show. How you
doing? I'm doing great. It's great to be
here, Tim. Amazing. Before we get
started, just a quick note. If you are
hiring in crypto, you should use Campus.
Out of all your candidates, help you
pick out the real crypto natives. Head
to the
block.co/campus to get a three-month
free trial. Now, today's episode is
around crypto grants funding. That's
obviously something that Thrive is
particularly focused on. So, what is
Thrive?
Yeah. So um Thrive is you know at this
point we believe the biggest builder
protocol in the space. We support over
hund00 million and committed capital
allocations from a lot of the top chains
in the space and we support builders and
founders and very quickly working uh in
crypto and and with top chains and
working in a way that creates value that
that creates GDP for the ecosystems that
they support.
And where did the idea for Thrive come
from? Like what what inspired it?
Yeah. So, I got into crypto way back in
2013. I read Satoshi's white paper and I
was really inspired by what I believed
was a treatise on fairness. This idea
that with this big open transparent
database, it doesn't matter who you are
or where you are or what your background
is. If you create value, you can and
should and will be rewarded
proportionate to the value you create.
Um, but I also believe that there was a
problem with the blockchain because the
blockchain is great at validating that a
transaction is valid, proving validity
of a transaction, but it's not great at
proving value. And I believed even way
back in 2013 that something like Thrive
would need to exist to help
decentralized communities to really
deeply um understand that value was
created and be able to reward it. So
even in November of 2013, I registered
the domain for Thrive. But it turns out
I was running another organization at
that time. It would take another eight
and a half years to sell that company
another few months for a friend to go on
a walk with the beach with me. And and
he said, "Yo, Daniel, whatever happened
to that Thrive idea of yours?" And I
wondered who had built it. And so I went
back and looked and nobody had. And I
realized that I had to found another
organization. And that was kind of the
beginning of Thrive.
Cool. So, so you were sort of aware of
crypto since 2013, but what point um
were you actively involved? Like did you
did you stay active throughout that
time? Um what was your journey like?
Yeah, I've been actively involved since
about four years ago when when I founded
Thrive. Um I had been involved in crypto
in different ways um beforehand, but
certainly not running a business. This
this is the first project, the first
organization that I've been a part of
within the context of of crypto. And you
know, some background on kind of what
Thrive does. We we actually built kind
of a a product, a protocol that
addresses sort of that major problem
that I noticed way back in 2013. So the
protocol is called Thrive Protocol. And
what it does is it proves that value uh
has occurred. And the way that it works
is when somebody creates something of
value, they submit evidence for that
through the protocol and that evidence
is routed to some number of either
certified experts, people who are
capable of reviewing whatever that
evidence is, data or code or financial
information and also some number of AI
agents that score in the upper cortile
of accuracy of those experts. And when a
threshold of them agreed, the value is
created. Then a thing is paid out and
it's attested to on chain. And what that
allows for is it allows foundations and
decentralized crypto communities for the
first time to make investments uh in you
know not just a few teams or people and
know that they're going to create value
aligned with what they promise but in
dozens or hundreds theoretically even
thousands of teams and know that they
effectively have 100% capital efficiency
with those investments. We really
believe that it's been gamechanging in
the space. Sure. So, how does that work
in terms of the people that review the
uh investments? Like, do they get paid
for it? What's their incentive? That's
exactly right. So, um they they get paid
in um you know, depending on uh the
orientation of the review. It could be
in um uh different currencies of the
communities that we support uh or now
that um they are also earning Thrive
points as they go too. But they only get
paid when they accurately review. So
they're heavily incentivized to review
accurately.
And who reviews the reviewers?
So um anybody can challenge a uh the
outcome of review? Um a reviewer who um
supposedly did not review accurately or
even the recipient uh so the contributor
or the builder uh whose product was uh
being reviewed. And that is effectively
reviewed by another level of reviewers
who um did not participate in the
original review and have a level of
accuracy that um entitles them to let's
call it a special badge, special access.
Okay. So you go to sort of a hierarchy
of review. That's exactly right. And uh
at what point did you start introducing
AI agents to the mix?
If we go back a year, we started to play
around with AI agents and that was a
very very small part of the process. It
was you know essentially all humans.
Today um it's effectively flipped. So
90% plus of reviews are done by AI
agents and um around 10% of reviews are
done by certified experts who um are you
know highly capable of of reviewing and
and against whom the AI agents accuracy
is being uh judged as well. Sure. And
how does um an AI agent review this
fully? So let's say the person's
claiming oh I've gone and built the the
protocol it's got so many users. How do
they prove that in a way that they the
AI agent can actually verify it like
properly? Yeah, I mean there has to be
um you know a very quantitative
understanding of exactly what it is
that's supposed to be reviewed and the
agent has to have access to u that
information in order to do the review.
Um, so it's really important that um,
when framing what needs to be reviewed
that that's being framed as accurately
and directly as possible.
And why did you end up like how come
you've got to the point where it's 90%
of agents reviewing it? Is it just
because it's more
efficient? What what sort of led to
that? I mean one of the really
interesting things that we noticed was
um great reviewers like experts um they
tend to review at an accuracy rate of
um my accuracy rate currently after
hundreds of reviews is 91%. uh maybe
it's crept up to 92, right? And when we
first started playing around with AI
agents, they were reviewing
significantly worse than great
reviewers. That's changed quite a bit,
right? So now their accuracy rate um uh
is generally extremely high. Again, it's
um as high or higher than top experts.
So with some agents, we're seeing 95,
96, 97% accuracy. And so really, it was
just a question of efficacy. Um we want
to be sure that at scale um uh work
products are being paid fairly and to be
paid fairly they need to be reviewed
fairly and um being reviewed fairly you
know is is really it's really a question
of accuracy whether we're talking about
humans or agents that are trained by
humans or other sort of um AI are you
using for this like in terms of like
which um platforms and then as you are
you modifying the AI AI or are you just
giving it custom instructions in order
you know to make it effective? Yeah. So
um we're constantly testing um you know
different agents or different platforms
against each other. We're agnostic about
the agent or the modality. Um really the
only thing that we care about is
accuracy and um and so Thrive being
agnostic to to modality it's it's really
important for us to continuously test
and that will always be the case.
How do you confirm the accuracy?
Right. So the accuracy initially is
confirmed because um there are a
threshold of experts and agents that
effectively find agreement and depending
on the type of thing being reviewed that
threshold can be different. I mean on
average usually it's around
70% but in some cases you want that

how we do the confirmation initially. If
it's the case that there's disagreement

goes to sort of a higher review

getting feedback, right, from those
those reviewers about um why it is that
uh whatever let's say the milestone was
that was confirmed was actually
confirmed or why it was not confirmed
and you know how they can uh improve

confirmation that they're looking for.
Okay. What's the biggest check? Yeah, go

And what we learned is effectively this.

um you know be potentially publicly

it's been a really exciting kind of

and you talk about um sort of its role

What are the biggest challenges to

There are a lot of challenges.

I mean, most of the ecosystems that

With with most human beings, even good

there's a very clear short-term path and

2018. Okay, obviously 2017 you had the
